name: Place, portraiture, performance
description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

key_work.title: Storyboarding in Ten Canoes
key_work.brief_description: Filmed in Arnhem Land with a cast of local Indigenous Australians, Ten Canoes interweaves two tales of forbidden love and consequence, spanning thousands of years of Yolngu storytelling, and is told entirely in language.

constellations_primary.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_primary.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

start.title: Moonlight
start.creator_credit: Adele Romanski, Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner, Altitude Film Entertainment and PASTEL
start.brief_description: The tender, heartbreaking story of a young man’s struggle to find himself, told across three defining chapters in his life as he experiences the ecstasy, pain, and beauty of falling in love, while grappling with his own sexuality.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

end.title: Three Times
end.creator_credit: Chang Hua-Fu, Huang Wen-Ying and Liao Ching-Sung
end.brief_description: There are three stories of women and men. In the first two stories, letters are crucial to the outcome; in the third, it’s cell-phone calls, text messages, and a computer file. Over the years between the tales, as sexual intimacy becomes more likely and words more free, communication recedes.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: Moonlight‘s structure, crossing the boundaries of three different time periods was inspired by Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien’s aptly-named 2005 film Three Times.

start.title: Storyboarding in Ten Canoes
start.brief_description: Filmed in Arnhem Land with a cast of local Indigenous Australians, Ten Canoes interweaves two tales of forbidden love and consequence, spanning thousands of years of Yolngu storytelling, and is told entirely in language.

constellations_primary.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_primary.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

end.title: Moonlight
end.creator_credit: Adele Romanski, Dede Gardner, Jeremy Kleiner, Altitude Film Entertainment and PASTEL
end.brief_description: The tender, heartbreaking story of a young man’s struggle to find himself, told across three defining chapters in his life as he experiences the ecstasy, pain, and beauty of falling in love, while grappling with his own sexuality.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: Just as Ten Canoes was inspired by anthropological photos of Ramingining from the 1930s, Barry Jenkins’ Oscar-winning Moonlight was inspired by Earlie Hudnall Jr’s 1970s portraits of African American communities in the American south.

start.title: The Tracker
start.brief_description: Somewhere in Australia in the early 20th century outback, an Aboriginal man is accused of murdering a white woman. Three white men are on a mission to capture him with the help of an experienced Indigenous man.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

end.title: Charlie's Country
end.brief_description: Charlie’s Country is a 2013 Australian drama film directed by Rolf de Heer. It was selected to compete in the Un Certain Regard section at the 2014 Cannes Film Festival where David Gulpilil won the award for Best Actor.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: David Dalaithngu and Rolf de Heer would go on to collaborate on a number of other projects, including Charlie’s Country.

end.title: The Tracker
end.brief_description: Somewhere in Australia in the early 20th century outback, an Aboriginal man is accused of murdering a white woman. Three white men are on a mission to capture him with the help of an experienced Indigenous man.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: As filming on David Dalaithngu and Rolf de Heer’s film The Tracker wrapped, Dalaithngu invited de Heer to his home of Ramingining to discuss making a film there. This new film would become Ten Canoes.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

end.title: Charlie's Country
end.brief_description: Charlie’s Country is a 2013 Australian drama film directed by Rolf de Heer. It was selected to compete in the Un Certain Regard section at the 2014 Cannes Film Festival where David Gulpilil won the award for Best Actor.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: In a courtroom scene in Charlie’s Country, David Dalaithngu’s character addresses the judge in his native language Yolngu-Matha. In 2012, the Aboriginal Interpreter Service staged a mock trial entirely in Yolngu-Matha in the Supreme Court of Darwin, with minimal translation available for a white defendant.

start.title: Charlie's Country
start.brief_description: Charlie’s Country is a 2013 Australian drama film directed by Rolf de Heer. It was selected to compete in the Un Certain Regard section at the 2014 Cannes Film Festival where David Gulpilil won the award for Best Actor.

constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

end.title: Carriberrie
end.brief_description: Narrated by award-winning actor and dancer David Gulpilil, Carriberrie guides audiences across a stunning array of iconic Australian locations and performances, from the traditional to contemporary.

constellations_other.name: Place, portraiture, performance
constellations_other.description: The nature of the collaboration between David Dalaithngu and Rolf De Heer on Ten Canoes connects the film to their other collaborations, and a number of other works as well.

links.description: A famed dancer himself, Dalaithngu also narrated the 2018 VR work Carriberrie, which presented traditional and contemporary Indigenous dances from around Australia.
